title: PlayStation 5 name and Christmas 2020 release date confirmed
text:
The PlayStation 5 is officially named (pic: Wired)

Sony has confirmed that their next console is called the PS5 and will be out this time next year, as they also hint at a new controller.

As obvious as the name and release date may be, this is the first time Sony has confirmed either – their only previous next gen talk being some vague details offered to Wired magazine back in April.

But as well as the console’s name and rough release date, Sony also talked about what will presumably be called the DualShock 5 controller, which will feature new haptic feedback instead of the more old-fashioned rumble tech in the current DualShock 4.

‘One of our goals with the next generation is to deepen the feeling of immersion when you play games, and we had the opportunity with our new controller to reimagine how the sense of touch can add to that immersion’, said PlayStation boss Jim Ryan on the PlayStation Blog.

‘With haptics, you truly feel a broader range of feedback, so crashing into a wall in a race car feels much different than making a tackle on the football field. You can even get a sense for a variety of textures when running through fields of grass or plodding through mud.’

‘The second innovation is something we call adaptive triggers, which have been incorporated into the trigger buttons (L2/R2)’, added Ryan.

‘Developers can program the resistance of the triggers so that you feel the tactile sensation of drawing a bow and arrow or accelerating an off-road vehicle through rocky terrain. In combination with the haptics, this can produce a powerful experience that better simulates various actions’

Ryan ended the short blog by re-confirming Death Stranding, The Last of Us Part II, and Ghost Of Tsushima as ‘PS4 exclusives’, with no suggestion of PlayStation 5 versions.

That in itself could be a hint at the PlayStation 5’s greater emphasis on backwards compatibility, but details on that will have to wait for a future update.

But after this it seems as if Sony is moving up a gear in terms of its next gen talk, so we’d expect to hear more fairly soon.
